ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about economic models and how to examine and evaluate the role that conflict played in the economies of different regions of the world.

I learned a lot about economic studies analyzing internal conflict (ex: how does a civil conflict in Peru affect capital accumulation, how do changes in commodity prices lead to changes in conflict in Colombia, et), and more importantly I learned a lot about how economic research is conducted, analyzing and interpreting regressions and causal models, finding errors and issues with economic papers, etc.

The main skill developed is how to read, comment on, describe, and truly understand economics papers. I don't think there's any better way to learn that than by taking this course! We also learned a lot about current/past events and conflict studies in general.
Very strong insights on what are the drivers of conflict.
Paper evaluation

I gained useful knowledge on reading and dissecting economic papers. I almost came to understand how complicated writing sad papers and doing the research for them is. I developed a newfound appreciation for the process of doing economic research
How to read an empirical econ paper, particularly how to evaluate empirical research designs like instrumental variables
Econometrics and how that relates to conflict
Understand how to read economics papers
Recognizing confounding factors in non-obvious places

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great class. Great professor. Assignments are manageable, fair, and interesting. Class presentations are neat and thoroughly done by students so it's usually interesting to sit through.

Strengths: Prof Padro is amazing. He's hilarious and really engaging and kind. Also, the workload is low.
Weaknesses: It's very very niche. If the syllabus doesn't interest you, you definitely shouldn't take it. If it does, then you'll love the course.

I think it's a great course. Prof. Padro is incredible, and the material is consistently engaging. The one potential weakness is that the workload wasn't at all balanced. On the weeks you had your presentation or reading response, it was a ton of work, but most of the rest of the class was not much work at all. So that's something to keep in mind, but not necessarily a net negative. Also, the class tended to be very quiet, so often it was more of a lecture than a seminar, but that might just have been our particular group of people.
The presentations are super engaging.
Engaging professor

Strengths: incredible professor and great structure with the reading responses and presentation. 
Weaknesses: honestly none. I think the course has been my favorite Econ course at yale

Strengths: design of reading assignments allowed for closer attention to readings in some weeks and less in others, cool content, wonderful teaching and intuitive explanations 

Weaknesses: none that I can think of

Strengths: readings, professor; weaknesses: random group of students in the class. I think it was meant to be more seminar style but it ended up just being presentations and Q&A/lecture. Professor Padro is really good at explaining things!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! One of the best ways to get the Econ Senior Seminar requirement knocked out.

The course is definitely very niche, but anyone signing up for it should be able to see that for themselves from the syllabus. So I can't say that the course would be better if it was more general, but it definitely felt very niche sometimes. I think that's the point though  we spent the class dissecting economic papers, one at a time, so that we could truly understand how these studies worked and how they came to their conclusions. In essence, it's a class that teaches you how economic research happens. So I would recommend this to another student if this is what they're looking for. 
Also, the workload is really doable and professor Padro is hilarious and so engaging.

Yes! The content is interesting, of course, but the best part is that it's sneakily a really good way to learn about econometrics and economics in an applied setting which makes everything much easier to understand.
Yes, you should defintley take it.
Yes if you really enjoy econometrics and looking at modern conflicts through a econometric lens.
Yes! Especially for EPE students

I really dont recommend this course. Student presentations make up the first 3/4 of every class, which are just summaries of the readings. Padro then takes questions for the latter 1/4, and he does not leave room for any discussion. That said, it is never clear what that discussion should involveif someone mentions a problem with a paper, Padro immediately jumps in with his opinion about the validity of the objection, rather than allowing genuine discussion/debate among students. 

Padro is also a punitive grader that does not offer specific steps for improvement; I feel like my grade was determined as soon as I stepped in the room. He refuses to help students understand the readings (many of which are written poorly/unclearly) before class, and he also does not ever explain what he considers to be an excellent paper. I never felt like any of my hard work translated into my grades. I regret spending so much time on all of his assignments.

Yes. This course is taught by the most engaging undergraduate economics professor at Yale. Professor Padro is truly a gem in the field of economics professor and taking a class with him is a terrific experience.
Yes! If you are at all interested in applied economics, this is a very fun course with a very reasonable workload where you will also learn a lot about empirical research designs
Yes... with caution? Our group discussion was quite bland but it wasn't Professor's fault. I think we tried but we aren't too good at econometrics and I think that was frustrating to our Prof. ?
Yes, if you're interested in the topic. Even if you're not, you'll learn along the way about economic experiment development and correlates of the economics of conflict.

Solid senior seminar for economics, the professor is clearly super knowledgeable and passionate about the subject, and has a great sense of humor which made class enjoyable. 
I would, however, advise against taking this class if you (like me) are not particularly interested in econometrics. The material can be quite challenging, and between the 9:25am class time and long presentations it can become hard to stay focused.
Yes - brilliant course brilliant prof
